content.title: Cushing Syndrome
content.summary: Clinical manifestations of prolonged glucocorticoid excess from exogenous steroids, pituitary ACTH overproduction (Cushing disease), ectopic ACTH, or adrenal tumors
key_points: Most common cause is exogenous/iatrogenic glucocorticoid use
Cushing disease = pituitary ACTH-secreting adenoma (most common endogenous cause)
Classic features: central obesity, purple striae, proximal myopathy, easy bruising
Screening tests: 24-hr urinary free cortisol, late-night salivary cortisol, 1-mg overnight DST
ACTH level distinguishes ACTH-dependent (pituitary, ectopic) from ACTH-independent (adrenal)
High-dose dexamethasone suppression and inferior petrosal sinus sampling localize source
Treatment depends on cause: surgical resection is first-line for endogenous Cushing
content.statement: Cushing syndrome encompasses the clinical manifestations of prolonged glucocorticoid excess from any source, requiring systematic evaluation to identify etiology and guide targeted treatment.

explanation.intuition: Cortisol is the body's stress hormone. In normal amounts it's essential, but chronic excess causes the body to break down - muscles weaken, bones thin, fat redistributes centrally, blood sugar rises, and the immune system becomes impaired.
explanation.key_insight: The diagnostic approach follows a logical sequence: First confirm hypercortisolism (screening tests), then determine if it's ACTH-dependent or independent (ACTH level), then localize the source (imaging, high-dose DST, IPSS). Each step narrows the differential.
explanation.technical_details: The hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis shows loss of normal diurnal rhythm and loss of negative feedback suppression. In Cushing disease, the pituitary adenoma retains partial negative feedback (suppresses with high-dose dexamethasone). Ectopic ACTH tumors typically do not suppress. CRH stimulation causes ACTH rise in pituitary Cushing but not ectopic sources.

definitions_glossary.cushings_syndrome: Clinical manifestations of chronic glucocorticoid excess from any source
definitions_glossary.cushings_disease: Cushing syndrome specifically caused by pituitary ACTH-secreting adenoma
definitions_glossary.acth_dependent: Hypercortisolism driven by excessive ACTH (pituitary or ectopic)
definitions_glossary.acth_independent: Hypercortisolism from autonomous adrenal cortisol production (adenoma, carcinoma, hyperplasia)
definitions_glossary.dexamethasone_suppression_test: Test using synthetic glucocorticoid to assess HPA axis suppressibility
definitions_glossary.urinary_free_cortisol: 24-hour urine collection measuring unbound cortisol excretion
definitions_glossary.late_night_salivary_cortisol: Test exploiting loss of circadian rhythm in Cushing syndrome
definitions_glossary.inferior_petrosal_sinus_sampling: Gold standard to distinguish pituitary from ectopic ACTH source
definitions_glossary.pseudo_cushings: States mimicking Cushing syndrome (depression, alcoholism, obesity) with mild hypercortisolism
definitions_glossary.ectopic_acth_syndrome: Non-pituitary tumors secreting ACTH (small cell lung cancer, carcinoid)
definitions_glossary.nelson_syndrome: Aggressive pituitary adenoma growth after bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing disease
definitions_glossary.adrenal_incidentaloma: Incidentally discovered adrenal mass that may produce excess cortisol

pathophysiology.mechanism: Prolonged elevation of glucocorticoids causing protein catabolism, fat redistribution, glucose intolerance, immune suppression, and bone loss

acth_dependent: Cushing disease - pituitary corticotroph adenoma (70% of endogenous cases)
Ectopic ACTH - small cell lung cancer, bronchial carcinoid, medullary thyroid cancer, thymoma

glucocorticoid_effects.protein_catabolism: Muscle weakness, skin thinning, easy bruising, poor wound healing
glucocorticoid_effects.fat_redistribution: Central obesity, moon facies, dorsocervical fat pad (buffalo hump)
glucocorticoid_effects.psychiatric: Depression, emotional lability, psychosis, cognitive impairment

clinical_presentation: Wide purple striae (>1 cm, on abdomen, thighs, breasts)
Proximal muscle weakness (difficulty rising from chair)

screening_tests.24hr_urine_free_cortisol: Elevated >3× upper limit of normal highly suggestive
screening_tests.late_night_salivary_cortisol: Loss of circadian rhythm; elevated late-night value
screening_tests.1mg_overnight_dst: Cortisol >1.8 μg/dL next morning fails to suppress (positive screen)
screening_tests.interpretation: Two or more positive tests confirm hypercortisolism

step_2_if_acth_dependent: Pituitary MRI (may be normal in microadenomas)
High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (Cushing disease usually suppresses >50%)
CRH stimulation test (Cushing disease shows ACTH rise; ectopic does not)
Inferior petrosal sinus sampling (IPSS) - gold standard for localization
etiologic_workup.step_3_if_acth_independent: Adrenal CT/MRI to identify adenoma, carcinoma, or hyperplasia

treatment_options.general_principles: Treat the underlying cause; normalize cortisol to prevent morbidity/mortality

pituitary_cushings_disease.first_line: Transsphenoidal surgery (TSS) for pituitary adenoma resection
pituitary_cushings_disease.second_line: Repeat surgery, pituitary radiation, medical therapy

treatment_options.ectopic_acth: Surgical resection of primary tumor if localized; medical therapy if occult or metastatic
treatment_options.adrenal_tumors: Unilateral adrenalectomy for adenoma; may need bilateral for carcinoma/hyperplasia
treatment_options.perioperative_management: Stress-dose hydrocortisone perioperatively; taper slowly as HPA axis recovers
treatment_options.bilateral_adrenalectomy: Last resort for uncontrolled disease; requires lifelong steroid replacement; risk of Nelson syndrome

skos.definition: Clinical manifestations of prolonged glucocorticoid excess from exogenous or endogenous sources requiring systematic evaluation and targeted treatment

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical features of glucocorticoid excess
Apply screening tests for Cushing syndrome (UFC, LNSC, 1-mg DST)
Use ACTH level to differentiate ACTH-dependent from independent causes
Localize ACTH source using high-dose DST, CRH stimulation, and IPSS
Select appropriate treatment based on underlying etiology
Manage perioperative glucocorticoid replacement after curative surgery
clinical_pearls: Wide purple striae (>1 cm) are highly specific for Cushing syndrome
Proximal muscle weakness distinguishes true Cushing from simple obesity
Two abnormal screening tests needed to confirm hypercortisolism
ACTH level is the single most important test after confirming hypercortisolism
50% of pituitary Cushing adenomas are too small to see on MRI - use IPSS
Hypokalemia suggests severe hypercortisolism or ectopic ACTH
After curative surgery, patients need glucocorticoid replacement until HPA axis recovers (months to years)
Nelson syndrome (aggressive ACTH-secreting tumor) can occur after bilateral adrenalectomy

step1_concepts: HPA axis regulation and negative feedback
Glucocorticoid effects on metabolism and immune function
common_questions: Obese patient with purple striae, easy bruising, and diabetes - evaluation?
Suppressed ACTH in patient with hypercortisolism - most likely cause?
Patient with elevated ACTH and negative pituitary MRI - next step?
